instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.U6903: What is U6903? This chip is responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H in 2016-2018 model Macbook logic boards.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
When battery is disconnected got 5V and 0.25A on charger on both ports.
With battery connected it turns on but on login screen trackpad/keyboard is not working.
Fan on high RPM and 5V and 0.0A on charger on one port.
Second USB C port got not reaction on USB C volt meter - it is linked with <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.

Diode mode value and voltages around <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> looks correct.

I think I will replace but how it can be related with no keyboard/trackpad?

Any idea?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
You should fix USB-C problem first.

Non working TP/KB may have other reason.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
Replaced that <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> and still got the same issue.

USBC meter shows all diode mode values are correct.

Any idea?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
Be sure J6700 gets all required voltages.
Try known good trackpad board/flex.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
"Replaced that <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> and still got the same issue."
When battery is disconnected got 5V and 0.25A on charger on both ports.
With battery connected 5V and 0A on one port and no reaction on USB C volt meter on another port.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message: You can't reach the login screen anymore?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message: I can but only when battery connected and when will do "jump start" when connect charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
You should fix the USB-C power problem.

Try to enter DFU using SE032 pads.

Did you test the board alone on the desk?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
"Try to enter DFU using SE032 pads."
no luck

"Did you test the board alone on the desk?"
yes, got 5V and 0.26A on charger and every a few seconds meter turns off and turn on (cycles).
<CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6903</CHIP> gets warm.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
Did you try to enter DFU using SE032 pads with both charger and battery connected?
You need to solder wire on the pads and cut off the wire when/if the machine appears in AC2.

Check if required SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages come on from <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
Soldered wire with SE032/3 and 4.
No DFU mode with battery and charger. The same without battery and charger.

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1.1V
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 0.79V

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.79V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 3.23V
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE 0.79V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 1.19V
<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> 0.75V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message: Keep TP/KB disconnected, when trying DFU with SE032 pads.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
No DFU mode with battery and charger. The same without battery and charger.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 100458, member: 682"]
Keep TP/KB disconnected, when trying DFU with SE032 pads.
[/QUOTE]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
Are you using correctly DFU jumper?
heck the example here:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://logi.wiki/index.php/DFU_Mode_Restore_(Macs)#/media/File:<SIGNAL>SOC_FORCE_DFU_JUMPER</SIGNAL>.jpg[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message: Please correct me if doing something wrong.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no keyboard/trackpad and 5V on charger
threads.message:
Connection is correct.
But you should use larger and tinest wire; this helps you tu cut it off.
